Mentioning the state of Georgia, a former Democratic congresswoman from the state of Georgia now takes up the banner of the Green Party, running for president.
Right, Cynthia McKinney, she was voted out of office in the 2006 primary.
She's widely known for two things.
One, she socked a security officer in the head with her cell phone because he refused to allow her to go through without showing identification.
And she, for the longest time, she suggested that the U.S.
knew in advance about the 9/11 attacks, which, of course, caused major - main - a lot of derision in the national, mainstream press.
But she does have a very strong constituency in the Green Party.
She's for - the impeachment of the president, she's for.
She blames not only the Republicans for the war, but also Democrat complicity, so she's obviously running against both Democrats and Republicans.
Two third-party candidates from Georgia, Bob Barr the Libertarian, and now Cynthia McKinney from Georgia, should make that state very interesting.
And well, I feel safe in saying I think we can get them on this show.
No.
But why not?
A lot of people say, well, why should we spend time on them, because they have no chance of winning?
But they do represent a point of view that's out there, and I think one of the things NPR serves is the opportunity to have that point of view broadcast.
Well, let's see if we can get another caller on the line for our trivia question.

Won the primary, lost the general election, right.

And before we duck away, big flap this week over the cover of the New Yorker Magazine, and again, if you haven't seen it, well, Barack Obama dressed in Muslim garb, Michelle Obama looking like Angela Davis, the U.S.
flag burning in the fireplace of the White House, where over it, there's a portrait of Osama bin Laden.
And some people said that was offensive.
(Soundbite of laughter)
No, but actually, look.
Look, it was a satire.
It was done in, you know, the New Yorker has done a lot of spoof covers.
Of course, this may not have worked.
A lot of Obama people are very upset.
Even John McCain said it was in poor taste.
It was an attempt at satire, obviously ridiculing the so-called arguments, the spurious arguments...
The rumors and lies, is what they're calling it.
Exactly - against Barack Obama, but it fell flat.
